column1: It was about nine o'clock in the morning when the ship first appeared. At once there was the greatest excitement in the village. It was a British warship. What would she do? Would she tack about in the bay to pick up stray coasters as prizes
column2: or would she land soldiers to burn the town? In either case there would be trouble enough.Those were sad days
column3: those old war-times in 1812. The sight of a British warship in Boston Bay was not pleasant. We were poor then
column4: and had no monitors to go out and sink the enemy or drive him off. Our navy was small
column6: though we afterwards had the victory and sent the troublesome ships away
column8: at that time they often came near enough
column9: and the good people in the little village of Scituate Harbor were in great distress over the strange ship that had appeared at the mouth of the harbor.
